content.text: Table 1.1 lists some SI quantities. Complete the table by indicating with a tick \((\checkmark)\) which rows are SI base quantities
Use the definition of power to determine its SI base units
SI base units .........

A light meter is used to measure the intensity of light in a classroom. Daylight is incident normally on the sensor of the meter. The sensor has an area of \(2.2 \text{cm}^2\). The reading on the meter is \(950 \text{W} \text{m}^{-2}\)
Calculate the power of the daylight incident on the sensor
Define acceleration
An Olympic diver stands on a platform above a pool of water, as shown in Fig. 2.1

When the diver is on the platform his centre of gravity is a vertical height of \(9.0 \text{m}\) above the surface of the water. The diver jumps from the platform with a velocity of \(5.9 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal
Air resistance is negligible
When the diver hits the surface of the water, his centre of gravity is a vertical height of \(1.2 \text{m}\) above the surface of the water
Calculate the speed of the diver at the instant he hits the surface of the water
Describe and explain the variation of the viscous drag force acting on the diver in the water as he moves downwards
The diver has a volume of \(7.5 \times 10^{-2} \text{m}^3\). The density of the water is \(1.0 \times 10^3 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\)
Show that the upthrust acting on the diver when he is entirely underwater is \(740 \text{N}\)

At a particular instant when the diver is entirely underwater his horizontal velocity is zero. The viscous drag force acting on him at this instant is \(950 \text{N}\) vertically upwards. The diver has mass \(78 \text{kg}\)
Determine the magnitude and direction of the acceleration of the diver
acceleration = .........\(\text{ms}^{-2}\)
direction
The diver in **(b)** enters the water and decelerates
Use Fig. 3.2 to calculate the force exerted on the wire by the model planet
The elastic potential energy of X is 0.31 J
Calculate the original length of the wire before the model planet was attached
original length = .........m
The strain in X is \(5.4 \times 10^{- 3}\)
Wire X is replaced by a new wire, Y, with the same original length and diameter but double the Young modulus of X. Wire Y also obeys Hooke's law
On Fig. 3.2, draw a line representing the variation with strain of the stress for Y
A thin metal wire X, of diameter \(1.2 \times 10^{- 3} \text{m}\), is used to suspend a model planet, as shown in Fig. 3.1
The variation with strain of the stress for wire X is shown in Fig. 3.2
Complete the equation for this decay
State the principle of conservation of momentum
Before the decay, nucleus P has a speed of \(3.2 \times 10^{5} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\). After the decay, nucleus Q is stationary
Calculate the speed of the alpha particle after the decay
A nucleus P undergoes \(\alpha \)-decay to form nucleus Q
By reference to the direction of propagation of energy, state what is meant by a transverse wave
A space telescope is designed to detect electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths in the range \(12 \mu \text{m}\) to \(28 \mu \text{m}\)
State the region of the electromagnetic spectrum for this radiation

A detector on another space telescope detects an electromagnetic wave. The signal from the detector is transmitted to Earth and displayed on an oscilloscope as shown in Fig. 5.1. The frequency of the signal displayed on the oscilloscope is equal to the frequency of the detected electromagnetic wave
The time-base setting on the oscilloscope is \(5.0 \times 10^{-15} \text{s} \text{cm}^{-1}\)
Calculate the wavelength of the detected electromagnetic wave
wavelength = .........m
Explain how the pattern of bright and dark interference fringes is formed
The distance between the centres of bright fringe X and bright fringe Y in the pattern is 10.2 mm. The slit spacing is 1.2 mm. The distance from the slits to the screen is 3.1 m
Calculate the wavelength of the light incident on the slits
wavelength = .........m
The light is replaced by different visible light with a shorter wavelength
State how the new fringe separation will compare to the original fringe separation
Coherent visible light of a single frequency is incident normally on a double slit. This produces a pattern of bright and dark interference fringes on a screen, as illustrated in Fig. 6.1
There are seven bright fringes
On Fig. 6.2, draw a cross \((\times)\) to show the position of a node
State the phase difference between P and Q
phase difference = .........
State the phase difference between P and R
phase difference = .........
A stationary wave is formed on a stretched string AB, as shown in Fig. 6.2
P,
Q and R are points on the string
Define electric potential difference
A cell of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(1.8 \text{V}\) and internal resistance \(r\) is connected in parallel with a resistor of resistance \(6.0 \Omega\) and a filament lamp, as shown in Fig. 7.1
The switch S is open. The ammeter reading is 0.25A
Determine the internal resistance \(r\) of the cell
State whether the e.m.f. of the cell after \(t_{1}\) is greater than, less than or the same as it was before \(t_{1}\)
By considering the effect of the lamp on the total resistance of the circuit, explain the variation of the ammeter reading shown in Fig. 7.2
At time \(t_{1}\) switch S in Fig. 7.1 is closed. Fig. 7.2 shows the variation with time \(t\) of the ammeter reading \(I\)
State the name of the class (group) of fundamental particles that contains a neutrino
Identify a possible flavour for this other quark
State what type of hadron is P
A hadron P has a charge of \(+1e,\) where \(e\) is the elementary charge. The hadron P is composed of a down antiquark and only one other quark
State what particle is represented by X
Compare the nucleon numbers of Q and R
Compare the charges of Q and R
Nucleus Q undergoes radioactive decay to form nucleus R, emitting an antineutrino and another particle X, as shown in the decay equation
